Rumahnya dibangun ditanah sendiri dengan bangunan yang cukup permanen. Pinjaman Dinari dipakai untuk menambah modal usaha dan mengembangkan usahanya.

loans.use: To buy more inventory and display racks

loans.name: Asma

texts.en:
Asma baji is the wife of M., and she lives in the city of Riwind, Pakistan. She owns a three-room, brick house, which she and her family have lived in for the last 26 years. Asma baji sells milk and takes care of her animals. In fact, Asma baji has been in the dairy business for the last 26 years. In addition, she is the mother of seven children: six daughters and one son. Her three oldest daughters are enrolled in a local school in neighborhood. Her husband, meanwhile, is a driver (he drives a rented vehicle).

Notably, Asma baji successfully repaid her three previous loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan). Currently, she is seeking another loan in order to buy a buffalo to expand her milk business.

loans.use: To expand and improve her dairy business by purchasing a buffalo

loans.name: Barkat

texts.en:
Barkat baji is the wife of H. M., and she lives in the city of Riwind, Pakistan. She owns a two-room, brick house, which she and her family have lived in for the last 28 years. Barkat baji is the mother of eight children: six sons and two daughters. Her husband has been selling milk for the last 20 years. Meanwhile, Barkat baji is a housewife, and she prefers to do work around their house and to take care of the children as well as the animals. Her four oldest sons work in a factory, while her other children (her two youngest sons and her daughters) are enrolled in a local school in her neighborhood.

Notably, Barkat baji successfully repaid three previous loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan). Now, she is applying for another loan in order to buy a buffalo and to expand her husband’s dairy business.

loans.use: To expand and improve her husband's dairy business by purchasing a buffalo

loans.name: Sarfraz

texts.en:
Sarfaraz Begum baji is the wife of A. H., and she lives in the city of Riwind, Pakistan. She has been living with her family in this city for the last 19 years. She owns a five-room, brick house. In general, Sarfaraz baji takes care of her children and her animals. Indeed, she has her work cut out for her as she is the mother of six children: two sons and four daughters. Her oldest son works in a bakery. Her husband, meanwhile, sells milk, and he has been in this profession for the last 10 years.

Notably, Sarfraz baji successfully repaid three previous loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan). Now, she is seeking another loan in order to buy a buffalo for her husband’s milk business.

loans.use: To expand and improve her husband's dairy business by purchasing a buffalo

loans.name: Begam

texts.en:
Begam bibi is the wife of S. A., and she lives in the city of Riwind, Paksitan. Begam baji is the mother of four children: two sons and two daughters. Her sons work in a factory and receive monthly wages, while her daughters are enrolled in a local school in her neighborhood. Begam baji is engaged in numerous activities on a daily basis: she sells milk, does household work, and takes care of her children and animals. Her husband, meanwhile, has been driving a tractor for the last 5 years.

Notably, Begam baji successfully repaid three previous loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan). Now, she is applying for another loan in order to buy a buffalo to expand her milk business.

loans.use: To expand and improve her dairy business by purchasing a buffalo

loans.name: Salma

texts.en:
Salma baji is the widow of F. H., and she has been living with her family in the city of Riwind, Pakistan for the last 25 years. She is the mother of three sons, all of whom work in a factory. Salma baji is a housewife, though she also runs a dairy business which she has operated for 20 years. Interestingly, Salma baji does not let her children realize that their father passed away. She has a dream to see her children in good professions.

Notably, Salma baji successfully repaid three previous loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan). Currently, she is applying for another loan in order to buy a buffalo for her milk business.

loans.use: To expand and improve her dairy business by purchasing a buffalo

loans.name: Rubina

texts.en:
Rubina baji is the wife of H. H., and she lives in the city of Riwind, Pakistan. She owns a two-room, brick house, which she has lived in for the last 30 years. Rubina baji is the mother of five children: two sons and three daughters. Her sons work in a factory and receive monthly income; her oldest daughter is in 9th standard; her next oldest daughter is in 5th standard; and her youngest daughter is in 4th standard. Meanwhile, Rubina baji’s husband drives a tractor, and he has been in this profession for the last 15 years.

Notably, Rubina baji successfully repaid three prior loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan). Now, she is applying for another loan in order to repair her husband's tractor (both the body and engine of the vehicle).

loans.use: To improve her husband's business by repairing her husband's tractor

loans.name: Rahat

texts.en:
Rahat baji is the wife of A. M., and she lives in the city of Riwind, Pakistan. She is the mother of five children: three sons and two daughters. Her oldest son sells milk; her other sons are in school (5th and 3rd standards, respectively); her oldest daughter works in a cotton Mill; and her younger daughter is in 7th standard.

Rahat baji makes embroidered dresses and generally does a lot of work around her house. Notably, Rahat baji successfully repaid three previous loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan). Currently, she is applying for another loan in order to buy a buffalo to expand her son's milk business.

loans.use: To buy a buffalo in order to expand and improve her son's milk-selling business

loans.name: Maxim

texts.en: Maxim was born in 1970. He is married, with 2 children. Maxim's wife is pictured. Maxim is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Kalbadjar region in the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan, now settled in the Absheron region, Masazir village. 9 years ago he started his produce business. Now the M. family needs a loan of $1200 to buy vegetables and fruits to improve their business.

loans.use: To buy vegetables and fruits

loans.name: Barkat

texts.en:
Barkat baji is the widow of M., and she has been living in the city of Riwind, Pakistan for the last 20 years. Barkat baji is the mother of four children: three sons and one daughter. Her oldest son has a shuttering business, and he has been in this profession for the last 10 years; her other sons work at a factory; and her daughter is in school (in 8th standard). Barkat baji is a housewife, and she prefers to do work around the house.

Importantly, Barkat baji successfully repaid three previous loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan). Now, she is seeking another loan in order to buy shuttering materials (beams and ropes) for her son’s shuttering business.

loans.use: To buy construction materials (beams and ropes) for her son's business

loans.name: Sajida

texts.en:
Sajida baji is the wife of M., and she has been living in the city of Riwind, Paksitan for the last 12 years. She lives in a house which is situated in an area known as Bhai Kot within Riwind. She is the mother of six children: two sons and four daughters, all of whom are enrolled in a local school in her neighborhood. Her husband, meanwhile, drives a tractor for a living, and he has been doing so for the last 10 years.

Notably, Sajida baji successfully repaid her three previous loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan). Currently, she is requesting another loan in order to repair a tractor (both the engine and the body of the vehicle).

loans.use: To repair the engine and body of a tractor

loans.name: Mwavu Teyebaka Women's Group

texts.en:
The Mwavu Teyebaka women's group was founded more than two years ago with Gertrude K. as chairperson. "Mwavu teyebaka" means the poor do not sleep.

Gertrude makes a living as a seamstress and fashion designer. She is 41 years old and has two children. For the last 10 years, she has operated a shop in Kampala that has two sewing machines. One is electric and the other is manual and brought into use when the electricity goes out. Gertrude makes casual wear for women along a traditional garment know as a busuuti. Her clients come to her shop to pick a pattern from one of her books.

Gertrude is applying for a loan to buy more material, especially bitenge cloth, which is very popular with her customers. In the photo, we see her loan group with its microfinance teacher, N. Phoebe.

loans.use: To buy cloth and embroidery materials.

loans.name: Ruqaiya

texts.en:
Ruqaiya baji is the wife of M. Ashraf, and she has been living in the city of Riwind, Pakistan for the last 7 years. She owns a two-room, brick house. Additionally, she is the mother of four children: two sons and two daughters. Her sons work in a cotton factory; her elder daughter sews clothes; and her younger daughter is a teacher in a local school. Her husband, meanwhile, is a watchman at a factory.

Ruqaiya baji has a milk business, and she has been selling milk for the last 20 years. Notably, she successfully repaid her three previous loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan). Now, she is seeking another loan in order to buy a buffalo to expand her milk business.

loans.use: To expand and improve her milk-selling business by purchasing a buffalo

loans.name: Tural

texts.en: Tural was born in 1986, is not married, and has settled in the town of Khirdalan. He is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of the Jabrail region in Azerbaijan. Tural has 2 years of experience with his billiard room business.  Now he needs a loan of $625 to buy the necessary things for improving his billiard room.

loans.use: To buy the necessary things for improving his billiard room

loans.name: Mtumwa's Kheri Liwe Group

texts.en:
Mtumwa is 35 years old. She is married with four children aged 3, 10, 13, and 17. She also takes care of one other child aged 18 years old. She has been in tailoring since 2002. She works each day from 7AM to 6PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 (US Dollars) in sales.

Mtumwa hopes for a loan to buy more tailoring items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, Nusura and Mwachoun, who also have businesses dealing in clothing sales.

loans.use: To buy more tailoring items for her business

loans.name: Amina's Ujamaa Group

texts.en:
Amina is 33 years old. She is married with five children aged between 3 and 17. She became a bites and tea seller in 2005. She works daily from 7AM to 9PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $140 (US Dollars) in sales.

Amina hopes for a loan to buy more bites to expand her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who also have businesses selling bread, clothing, charcoal, juice, soap, and perfumes.

loans.use: To expand her business by buying more bites items

loans.name: Ochiloy

texts.en:
Ochiloy I. is 37 years old. She is divorced and the mother of three children. After the divorce from her husband, Ochiloy had to find ways to provide for herself and her three children. For ten years she has had a business baking and selling the national bread “lepeshka”. It has now become a family business as the children of Ochiloy are grown-up and they are helping their mother.

Ochiloy is a cheerful, hard worker despite the difficulties she faces. She has received and repaid two loans from IMON which have helped create stability for her business. Today Ochiloy is requesting a loan of 1000 USD with a term of 12 months. She is planning to purchase flour and coal required for baking the national bread, “lepeshka”. This purchase will enable her to increase her sales, to earn more so she can provide her children with a good education. With your help this will be possible.

loans.use: Purchasing flour and coal required for baking the national bread, “lepeshka”.

loans.name: Umeda

texts.en:
Umeda I. is 35 years old. She and her husband have got one son. For a long time, Umeda’s husband couldn’t find a proper job for himself and currently he is working in Russia. To improve her family position, Umeda started her business 13 years ago. Because she does not have a specialized education, baking the national bread "lepeshka" is the only source of income for her family. She bakes the “lepeshka” at home. Her son helps her with the business.

Having the customers, Umeda is selling the majority of her products just from her home. However, she is also running a stall in the central market, selling the ”lepeshka”. Having only one son, Umeda is doing her best to assure him of the best future.

Now Umeda is requesting a loan in the amount of 1000 USD for a term of 12 months. She is planning to purchase the flour required for her business wholesale. From the profit of her business, Umeda wants to send her son to the University as she is dreaming her son might be well educated. She wants to keep educating him because she hopes that he reaches the goals that he has laid out for himself. With your help this will be possible. Umeda is grateful for all supporting her and promises to manage the loan with accuracy.

loans.use: Purchasing flour for baking the national bread “lepeshka” wholesale

loans.name: Maryam's Tuwe Na Moyo Group

texts.en:
Maryam is 36 years old. She is married with two children, ages 13 and 15. She has been a pot maker since 1997. She works daily from 7AM to 9PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 (US Dollars) in sales.

Maryam hopes for a loan to expand her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, Saada and Raya, who also have businesses dealing with soap sales, clothing sales, and tailoring.

loans.use: To improve her business

loans.name: Muamini

texts.en:
Muamini is 30 years old. She is married with two children ages 1 and 10. She began tailoring in 2002. She works daily from 7AM to 8PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 (US Dollars) in sales.

Muamini hopes for a loan to buy more tailoring items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more tailoring items to improve her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy new items to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Vann

texts.en: Vann P., 46, is a rice farmer who lives in Siem Reap with her husband, Nginh Nghor, and their six children. Her husband works in construction, repairing and building roads for the city, making US$2.50 each day, while one of the children also works on roads and makes the same income. Vann P. would like to expand her farm and increase her yields, allowing her to sell more crops in the local market. She has asked for a loan of US$300 to purchase more rice seeds to expand her crops.

loans.use: Vann would like to purchase more rice seeds for her farm.

loans.name: Sayora

texts.en: R. Sayora is 38 years old, married and the loving mother of three children. Sayora’s husband is currently unemployed, so her business is the main source of income for her family. Sayora runs a grocery store where she is sells detergents, sweets, juices, soft drinks and other food items. She has been in this business for three years. The inventory she has for sale is high quality and carefully selected, and Sayora takes good care of all of her customers, which explains why so many of them return to buy groceries again. Sayora is seeking to keep her business growing by applying for a loan of $750 for 12 months. She will use the loan to increase the number of items she has for sale. One of her dreams is that her children can get ahead through eduction, and for this she is willing to make great sacrifices, particularly to send them to university. We believe the current loan will enhance the potential of her business and help Sayora reach all of her aspirations.

loans.use: To buy additional items to sell.

loans.name: Maryam

texts.en:
Maryam is 27 years old. She is married with three children aged 4, 8, and 9. She also takes care of one other person aged 19 years old. She has been selling chips since 2003. She works daily from 7AM to 8PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $90 (US Dollars) in sales.

Maryam hopes for a loan to buy more potatoes for her business selling chips.

loans.use: To improve her business by increasing her inventory

loans.name: Mashhura

texts.en: Mashhura Z. is 32 years old and married. She makes a living in Penjikent as a small entrepreneur who sells women’s shawls, tights, brassieres and other items from a stall in the central market. She began this business because her husband's salary was not high enough to meet all of their needs. Mashhura has run her business for six years and has done quite well, surviving some initial challenges, then growing, and now providing excellent service and innovative products. She has come to Kiva for a loan of $1,025 to re-stock her merchandise. This will help her generate additional income with new goods and increased sales. Mashhura is counting on your help, and would like to thank everybody who chooses to support her. She promises to repay the loan in 12 months.

loans.use: To buy additional items to sell to her customers

loans.name: Veysal

texts.en: Veysal was born in 1960; he is married, with 2 children.  He is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Jabrail region in the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan, now settled in the town of Khirdalan. Veysal has run a taxi business for 10 years. Now he is requesting a loan of $625 to buy spare parts to maintain his taxi.

loans.use: To buy spare parts

loans.name: Bakusekamajja Women's Group

texts.en:
L. Maritine has been the chair of Bakusekamajja women's group in Jinja for the last eight years. She is 50 years old, married with four children and also cares for eight orphans. For a living, she makes malwa, a local brew and delicacy among the people of her tribe. She also sells dried fish at her home.

Making malwa takes times and begins by mixing millet flour with water and putting it underground for several days to ferment. Then it is boiled and dried in the sun to rid it of any water. More mixing, drying and grinding is required before it becomes a beverage which is placed in pots from which people drink with straws. This is a good business to be in because people prize the way in which malwa creates a spirit of togetherness and sharing.

Maritine needs a loan to buy more dried fish to sell at her stall and more materials for making malwa. She dreams of starting a business making and selling waragi, another local drink, with a future loan.

loans.use: Lulua Maritine needs a loan to be able to buy more dry fish for sell at her stall as well as buying the malwa making materials like millet flour and a metallic basin for roasting.

loans.name: Yusif

texts.en: Yusif A. is 43-year-old man who sells spare car parts in the Imishli region. He has more than 15 years of experience in this field. He has applied for 1200 USD to improve the conditions in his store.

loans.use: Improve condition of store

loans.name: Sa

texts.en: Sa P., 43, lives in Siem Reap with her husband, Thoan Soeung, and their eight children. Sa P. stays at home to manage this large family, while her husband works as a fisherman making US$5 each day from selling his catch in the local food market. One of their children works at a local golf course, while three others sell various food products, and the rest are too young to be employed. Sa P. has asked for a loan of US$1000 to open up a food stand that sells roast beef and drinks. Previously, she had been employed in a similar food stand and now she believes she has the experience necessary to open her own business. She looks forward to watching this new enterprise grow and is optimistic about her investment.

loans.use: Sa would like to open up her own food stand, selling roast beef and drinks.

loans.name: Tatu's Jambo Nia Group

texts.en:
Tatu is 25 years old. She is married with two children ages 4 and 5. She became a charcoal and soap seller in 2008. She works daily from 6AM to 8PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $50 (US Dollars) in sales.

Tatu hopes for a loan to buy more charcoal and soap for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who also have businesses dealing in juice sales, perfume sales, and tailoring.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and soap for her business.

loans.name: Sok

texts.en: Mrs. SOK Y. is a villager in Prey Pouch Village in Kampong Chhnang Province, Cambodia. She is a housewife who  cooks delicious food for her family. Her husband, Mr. Chan Kosal, is a soldier who makes a small salary to support his family. Mrs. SOK Y. is 55 years old and the mother of a child who is employed in a garment factory. Since her family lives in an old house and in poor conditions, Mrs. SOK Y. has decided to request a loan to add to her savings to build a new house for her family. Her husband is also in the photo.

loans.use: To add to her savings to build a new house for her family in order to improve her standard of living.

loans.name: Hidaya's Jambo Nia Group

texts.en:
Hidaya is 24 years old. She is married with one child aged 9 months. She is a teacher and bites seller. She started this business in January 2008. She works daily from 8AM to 8PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $25 (US Dollars) in sales.

Hidaya hopes for a loan to expand her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who also have businesses selling soft drinks, bites, and porridge.

loans.use: To expand her business.

loans.name: Murad

texts.en: Murad  is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Agdam region in the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan. He is married, with 3 children. This man settled in a student hostel of Baku State University which is in Baku city, Yasamal region. 15 years ago he started selling "Doner". Now he needs a loan of $625 to buy meat to cook into tasty "Doner" so he can earn more income.

loans.use: to buy meat

loans.name: Qurban

texts.en:
Qurban A. is a 32-year-old man who keep his own store where he has sold spare car parts since 1994. He lives and works in a small southern village of the Imishli region. He is married and has 1 daughter, looks after his parents who live with him in his house. To improve his living conditions he needs to expand his business by purchasing more spare parts to sell. For this purpose he has applied for 1200 USD.

Qurban previouosly took a loan form AqroInvest and successfully repaid it.

loans.use: Expand his business by purchasing more spare parts to sell

loans.name: Cheng

texts.en: Mrs. CHENG S. M. is a pig breeder in Tbeng Village in Kampong Chhnang Province, Cambodia.She previously obtained a loan to start her business and she has paid it back in full. Since Mrs. CHENG S. M.'s business is going well, she would like to to expand and is now requesting a loan to buy additional piglets for breeding. Any remaining money from the loan would be used to buy pig food to feed them. Her husband, Mr. Soy Sokhoeurn, is a teacher who makes a small salary to support his family. Aside from teaching, he is a Khmer traditional healer who sells traditional Cambodian medicines in the local village. Mrs. CHENG S. M. has six children, four of whom are attending school while the others are too young to work or study. Mrs. CHENG S. M. and her husband are shown in the picture.

loans.use: To buy additional piglets for breeding.

loans.name: Thi Huong's Group

texts.vi:
Mrs. N. Thi Huong (ID Number 03040010), born in 1954, would like to borrow 4,028,000VND to invest in rearing chickens and geese. Currently, she has about 200 geese and 100 chickens. She also plants fruit trees and vegetable to sell. Her children are all grown up and working, thus earning stable income. Her family's average monthly income is 4,500,000VND (about 300USD). She will use this loan to purchase more animal feeds as well as more geese and chickens to breed. Her group also consists of:
  • Mrs. Tong Thi Van (ID Number 03040014), born in 1980, would like to borrow 4,028,000VND to invest in raising livestock.
  • Mrs. N. Thi Lan (ID Number 03040009), born in 1969, would like to borrow 4,028,000VND to invest in her pharmaceutical store.
  • Mrs. N. Thi Phuong (ID Number 03040066), born in 1981, would like to borrow 2,204,000VND to sell construction supplies.
  • Mrs. N. Thi Thuy Van (ID Number 03040013), born in 1972, would like to borrow 1,908,000VND to invest in raising livestock.
  • Mrs. N. Thi Doan (ID Number 03040011), born in 1980, would like to borrow 4,028,000VND to sell construction supplies.
  • Mrs. N. Thi Thuy (ID Number 03040012), born in 1983, would like to borrow 1,972,000VND to invest in raising livestock.
  • The total amount requested is 1,350.00USD.

    • Translated from Vietnamese by Pham Yen Thanh, Kiva Volunteer.

    Nguyễn Thị Hường, sinh năm 1954 (Ms 03040010), mức vay: 4.028.000 vnđ để đầu tư trang trại nuôi gà, ngan. Hiện trang trại của gia đình cô có khoảng 200 con ngan và 100 con gà. Ngoài ra, cô còn trồng cây ăn quả và trồng rau. Các con cô đều đã trưởng thành đi làm và có thu nhập. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình cô khoảng 4.500.000 vnđ / tháng. Lần vay vốn này gia đình cô sẽ sử dụng vào việc mua thức ăn cho ngan, gà và mua thêm con giống. Trong nhóm cô còn có: Tống Thị Vân, sinh năm 1980 (Ms 03040014), mức vay: 4.028.000 vnđ để đầu tư chăn nuôi. Nguyễn Thị Lan, sinh năm 1969(Ms 03040009), mức vay: 4.028.000 vnđ để đầu tư cửa hang thuốc. Nguyễn Thị Phương, sinh năm 1981(Ms 03040066), mức vay: 2.204.000 vnđ để kinh doanh vật liệu xây dựng. Nguyễn Thị Thúy Vân, sinh năm 1972(Ms 03040013), mức vay: 1.908.000 vnđ để đầu tư chăn nuôi. Nguyễn Thị Doan, sinh năm 1980 (Ms 03040011), mức vay: 4.028.000 vnđ để kinh doanh vật liệu xây dựng. Nguyễn Thị Thủy, sinh năm 1983 (Ms 03040012), mức vay: 1.972.000 để đầu tư chăn nuôi.

loans.use: Rearing chickens and retailing

loans.name: Amil

texts.en: Amil I., 23, operates a wholesale food store in the Imishli central bazaar. He has six years of experience in this field. As the oldest son in his family, Amil tries very hard to cover all of his family's needs. To improve his life he needs to increase the inventory of foodstuffs that he sells, so for this purpose he is requesting a loan of $1000.  Amil thanks you for your interest and support.

loans.use: To increase the inventory of foodstuffs for sale

loans.name: Cheng

texts.en: Mr. CHENG S. C. is a villager in Tbeng Village in Kampong Chhnang Province, Cambodia. He sells traditional Cambodian medicine from which he can make a small income to support his family. His wife, Mrs. Non Na, is a pig breeder. She does not have enough money to purchase feed for the pigs S. Mr. CHENG S. C. requests a loan for her business. Mr. CHENG S. C. is 30 years old and is the father of a young child who cannot work or study. He had previously obtained a loan from AMK to purchase additional Khmer traditional medicine to resell and he has fully paid it back. His wife is shown in the photo.

loans.use: To buy pig feed for his wife's business.

loans.name: Yagud

texts.en: Yagud B. is a 42-year-old woman who sells dairy products such as milk and yoghurt in the Imishli region. She started her business in 1989. She is married and has 2 sons. As selling dairy products is the only financial resource in her family, Yagud would like to expand her business and purchase three additional calves for an estimated cost of 300 USD each and fodder for the remaining 100 USD.

loans.use: to purchase 3 calves and fodder

loans.name: Thi Ha's Group

texts.vi:
Mrs. N. Thi H. (ID Number 10080005), born in 1984, would like to borrow 2,204,000VND to rear pigs. Mrs. H. is a seamstress. Everyday both her husband and she go to work. Her husband works as a construction worker while she works as a seamstress for a clothing firm, earning stable income. Her family's average monthly income is about 3,000,000VND (about 200USD). Besides the main income from work, she also rear pigs to earn additional income. Her family's monthly income is only just enough to pay for living expenses so she does not have enough capital to do business. Therefore, she ventures into raising livestock and is voted to be the group leader. Her group also consists of:
  • Mrs. V. Thi Thuy Hao (ID Number 10080018), born in 1980, would like to borrow 2,204,000VND to breed chicken.
  • Mrs. T. Le Quyen (ID Number 10080019), born in 1982, would like to borrow 2,436,000VND to invest in her clothes shop.
  • Mrs. H. Thi Ai (ID Number 10080021), born in 1970, would like to borrow 2,204,000VND to start a tailoring business.
  • Mrs. N. Thi Phuong (ID Number 10080020), would like to borrow 2,204,000VND to sell vegetables.
  • The total amount requested is 700.00USD.

    • Translated from Vietnamese by Pham Yen Thanh, Kiva Volunteer.

    Nguyễn Thị Hà, sinh năm 1984 (Ms 10080005), mức vay: 2.204.000 vnđ để đầu tư chăn nuôi lợn. Chị Hà là thợ may. Hàng ngày hai vợ chồng chị đều đi làm, chồng chị làm thợ xây, bản thân chị làm may tại xưởng may công nghiệp có thu nhập ổn định. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng 3.000.000 vnđ / tháng. Ngoài thu nhập từ tiền công đi làm, chị còn chăn nuôi thêm lợn để tăng thu nhập. Lương của hai vợ chồng chị chỉ đủ trang trả sinh hoạt hàng ngày nên chị thiếu vốn làm ăn. Chính vì thế chị đã mạnh dạn vay vốn để đầu tư chăn nuôi và chị được bầu làm nhóm trưởng nhóm vay vốn. Trong nhóm chị gồm có: Vương Thị Thúy Hảo, sinh năm 1980 (Ms 10080018), mức vay: 2.204.000 vnđ để đầu tư chăn nuôi gà. Trần Lệ Quyên, sinh năm 1982 (Ms 10080019), mức vay: 2.436.000 vnđ để đầu tư mở rộng hàng may mặc. Hà Thị Ái, sinh năm 1970 (Ms 10080021), mức vay: 2.204.000 vnđ để làm nghề may mặc. Nguyễn Thị Phượng (Ms 10080020), mức vay: 2.204.000 vnđ để đi chợ rau.

loans.use: Rearing pigs

loans.name: Pary

texts.en:
Pary is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Fuzuly region in the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan. She is now settled in the city of Baku, Yasamal region.

Pary was born in 1959. She is married, with two children. Pary has been in business for 8 years, baking and selling bread. She is requesting a loan of $1200 to purchase flour and other products for use in the baking and selling of her bread.

loans.use: To purchase flour and other products for baking bread

loans.name: Ou

texts.en: Mrs. OU M. is a pig breeder in Tbeng Village in Kampong Chhnang Province, Cambodia. Aside from breeding pigs, Mrs. OU M. buys and sells baskets. Her husband, Mr. Sareth Koe, sells traditional Cambodian medicines. They have two children who are attending school. In order to improve their living conditions, Mrs. OU M. wants to start cultivating rice. She is now requesting a loan to add to her savings in order to to purchase a piece of land to grow the rice. Mrs. OU M. had previously obtained a loan to start her husband's business and she has paid it back in full. Her husband is also in the photo.

loans.use: To add to her savings in order to to purchase a piece of land to grow rice.

loans.name: Chang

texts.en:
Mrs. Chang D. is a 26-year-old pig raiser earning approximately $2.00 per day, while her husband, Mr. Lat Bunly, 25, produces palm juice that he processes into palm sugar, earning approximately $2.00 per day from sales. They live with one child in Omperl Commune, Siem Reap Province.

Mrs. D. is requesting a loan of $100 to purchase more small pigs to raise so as to improve the family’s income. In the future she wants all of her children to be well-educated and graduate from university in order to secure good jobs and help support the family.

About Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL): HKL is one of Cambodia's largest and most successful microfinance institutions (MFIs). It is committed to helping its clients achieve their business goals by providing sound financial services, and thereby hopes to contribute to the social and economic development of Cambodia. HKL specifically targets women and poor families in order to help them achieve increased financial security and quality of life by offering various credit programs and encouraging savings. In accordance with its mission and its commitment to operational and financial sustainability, HKL contributes part of its net profits every year to support social development in education and healthcare.

loans.use: To purchase more small pigs to raise

loans.name: Bakhruz

texts.en:
Bakhruz J. is a 31-year-old man who has been making windows of wood in a small village in the Imishli region since he was very young. He started learning this handicraft when he was 15 and his father was his main teacher. This is the main financial resource for their family.

Bakhruz is married and has 2 children. He would like to improve conditions in his carpentry shop and purchase modern machines and tools. For this purpose he has applied for a loan in the amount of 1200 USD.

loans.use: purchase modern machines and tools for carpentry

loans.name: Toa

texts.en:
Toa R., 29, is a young farmer living in Siem Reap with her husband, Lea Lam, and their two children. She raises pigs out of her home, making the wine that is used to help them grow large quickly. She typically makes US$2 per day, while her husband works their field making US$3 per day. Toa R. has asked for a loan of US$1000 to purchase a pair of cows to help her husband with the field work. They can be valuable as plows and the family believes the benefits that two cows can provide to the family's farm will be enough to increase their income and improve their business. They are optimistic about this investment and they look forward to the relief that these cows will provide to the work on the farm.

Toa R. was unavailable for a photograph at the time of the interview, so her husband is pictured above.

loans.use: Toa would like to purchase cows to help around the farm.

loans.name: Tahir

texts.en: Tahir is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Kalbadjar region in the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan, now settled in the Sabunchu region. He was born in 1963. This man is married, with 4 children. 3 years ago he started his perfume business. Now he needs a loan of $1200 to buy a lot of perfumes to improve his business.

loans.use: To buy a lot of perfumes

loans.name: Văn Ky's Group

texts.vi:
Mr. V. Van Ky (ID Number: 13040013), 48 years old, lives at Cau Giua, Yen Phu village. He has two children, the first one is currently in college while the second one is in high school. Everyday, Mr. Ky stays at home to sell animal feeds while his wife goes to the market to sell fruits and fresh bamboo shoots. Therefore, his family's income is very stable, as the daily total income is about 150,000VND (about 10USD). He likes to join the SEDA Fund and obtain loans to invest in his business, because It is very convenient to repay the loans on an installment basis. Thus, Mr. Ky would like to borrow 3,186,000VND to expand his business. His group also consists of:
  • Mrs. P. Thi Ly (ID Number 13040014), would like to borrow 3,186,000VND to sell fruits.
  • Mrs. Duong Thi Tam (ID Number 13040016), would like to borrow 3,186,000VND to open a general store at home.
  • Mrs. Nguyen Thi Anh (ID Number 13040015), would like to borrow 3,186,000VND to sell clothes.
  • The total amount requested is 900.00USD.

    • Translated from Vietnamese by P. Yen Thanh, Kiva Volunteer.

    Anh Vũ văn Kỷ năm nay 48 tuổi anh đang sinh sống tại thôn Cầu Giữa-xã Yên Phụ. MS 13040013,vợ chồng anh chị sinh được 2 con cháu thứ nhất đang học Đại học, cháu thứ hai đang học cấp III.Hàng ngày anh ở nhà bán thức ăn gia súc, còn vợ đi chợ buôn bán hoa quả và măng tươi.Vì vậy mức thu nhập của gia đình anh rất ổn định, mỗi ngày 2 vợ chồng thu nhập được khoảng 150.000 VND / ngày. Anh rất thích tham gia vay vốn của chương trình để có thêm nguồn vốn kinh doanh, đồng thời rất thuận tiện cho việc hoàn trả, nên anh đăng ký vay mức 3.186.000 VND để mở rộng kinh doanh. Các thành viên trong nhóm của anh là :

  • chị Phạm thị Lý MS 13040014 chị đăng ký vay mức 3.186.000 VND để bán hàng hoa quả
  • chị D. thị Tâm MS 13040016 chị đăng ký vay mức 3.186.000 VND để bán hàng tạp hoá tại nhà
  • chị Nguyễn thị Anh MS 13040015 vay mức 3.186.000 VND để kinh doanh buôn bán quần áo
  • chị Nguyễn thị Hương MS 13040017 vay mức 2.006.000 VND để kinh doanh

loans.use: Selling animal feeds and retailing

loans.name: Tatu

texts.en: Tatu Iddi is a Tanzanian entrepreneur. She is married and has three children. She runs a salon business in Buguruni in Dar-es-Salaam, Tanzania. Her business is three years old. Her business dream is to run a big and more modern beauty salon, but capital is a limiting factor. She is requesting a loan to expand her business.

loans.use: Expand her business

loans.name: Thi Tuyet's Group

texts.vi:
Mrs. D. Thi Tuyet (ID Number 05030050), born in 1962, would like to borrow 1,972,000VND to purchase bamboo to make brooms. She has two children who are already grown up and working, earning stable income. Her husband works as a hired worker. Besides making brooms, Mrs. Tuyet also rears cattle and sells drinks so she has a daily income. Her family's average monthly income is about 4,000,000VND (about 267USD). She is voted to be the group leader as she is responsible and reliable. She promises that she will repay the loan fully and that she will work hard to increase her family's income and improve their standard of living. Her group also consists of:
  • Mrs. N. Thi Loan (ID Number 05030006), born in 1957, would like to borrow 2,900,000VND to rear pigs.
  • Mrs. C. Thi Van (ID Number 05030051), born in 1966, would like to borrow 1.972,000VND to purchase raw materials to make brooms.
  • Mrs. C. Thi Bich (ID Number 05030008), born in 1974, would like to borrow 1,972,000VND to invest in her general store.
  • Mrs. N. Thi Khanh Hong (ID Number 05030052), born in 1952, would like to borrow 1,972,000VND to invest in her general store.
  • The total amount requested is 650.00USD.

    • Translated from Vietnamese by Pham Yen Thanh, Kiva Volunteer.

    Đinh Thi Tuyết, sinh năm 1962 (Ms 05030050), mức vay: 1.972.000 vnđ để đầu tư mua tre làm chổi nan. Vợ chồng chị có hai con đã trưởng thành, đi làm có thu nhập ổn định. Chồng chị hàng ngày đi làm thuê, bản thân chị ngoài chăn nuôi chị còn có nghề làm chổi, bán nước giải khát nên có thu nhập theo ngày. Thu nhập của gia đình chị khoảng :4.000.000 vnđ / tháng. Chi là người có uy tín nên những người trong nhóm vay vốn bầu chị làm nhóm trưởng. Được vay vốn gia đình chị hứa hoàn trả đầy đủ và cố gắng làm việc để tăng thu nhập và nâng cao mức sống. Trong nhóm chị còn có; Nguyễn Thị Loan, sinh năm 1957 (Ms 05030006), mức vay: 2.900.000 vnđ để chăn nuôi lợn. Chử Thị Vân, sinh năm 1966 (Ms 05030051), mức vay :1.972.000 vnđ để mua nguyên liệu làm chổi. C. Thị Bích, sinh năm 1974 (Ms 05030008), Mức vay: 1.972.000 vnđ để buôn bán nhỏ. Nguyễn Thị Khánh Hồng, sinh năm 1952 (Ms 05030052), mức vay: 1.972.000 vnđ để buôn bán nhỏ.

loans.use: Making brooms and retailing

loans.name: Chim

texts.en: Chim L. S., 61, sells vegetables in the local food market while her husband, Yim Sophat, is a private doctor. She typically makes US$50 each day in revenue, working as a middle man, purchasing vegetables from the growers and reselling them in the market. Her husband makes US$15 per day of income and they have six children who have all married and have started their own families outside the home. She has asked for a loan of US$1000 to allow her to purchase a larger amount of vegetables to resell in the market. She has seen that there is client demand for the goods, but she lacks the capital needed to expand her business. This investment will allow her to increase her daily profits and she is optimistic about the investment.

loans.use: Purchase more vegetables to resell

loans.name: Bahadur

texts.en: Bahadur was born in 1960. He is married, with 4 children. This man is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Lachin region in the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan, now settled in the city of Baku, Biladjary settlement. He makes window bars and installs the bars in his clients' windows.  He has been in this business for 4 years. Now he needs a loan of $1200 to buy material to make window bars.

loans.use: to buy the material to make window bars

loans.name: Klang

texts.en: Klang S., 62, is a widow who sells a traditional Khmer noodle soup dish out of her home food stand in Siem Reap. She lives with her one child who is a construction worker, and she has been serving soup to her community making US$5 per day. She has seen the demand for her dish grow and has asked for a loan of US$500 to expand and improve her business. She needs more eating utensils to satisfy all of her customers and would also like to expand her stand. There is room for her to add more seating and she feels that the customer demand is high enough to increase her income and account for this investment.

loans.use: Purchase more eating utensils and improve her stand

loans.name: Nazifa

texts.en:
Nazifa is a 44-year-old married woman from the town of Tesanj. Her husband found a job abroad working for a construction firm, and now works mainly in Croatia. Nazifa has been working in agriculture, growing vegetables including tomatoes, peppers, and potatoes.

This is Nazifa's 2nd loan with Zene za Zene, and she is requesting 1200 KM in order to buy chickens. It is her wish to fatten and sell these chickens for a profit. Luckily she has enough corn growing to feed them, so besides this purchase, she will not have any additional expenses. Nazifa is still waiting for the next crop of vegetables to be ready to harvest, and wants something more to do so she can make some additional income this year.

Here is a picture of Nazifa, who unfortunately could not be pictured at her home business. The credit officer covering her territory is out of town, and to get her loan posted Nazifa was met in town by Zene za Zene staff.

loans.use: To buy chickens for fattening and selling

loans.name: Faida's Asaa Khery Group

texts.en:
Faida is a 45 year old married woman with 4 children, aged 30,18,16 and 10. She has been in business as a tailor and selling charcoal since 1995. Every day, she works from 7 A.M. to 12 P.M. at her business where she can earn a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

Faida now hopes for a loan to buy more tailoring items and charcoal for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses selling juice, charcoal, firewood and clothing.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and tailoring items for her business

loans.name: Tabitha

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! Tabitha is a thirty-six-year-old married woman with three children between the ages of five and fourteen. She lives in Dar es Salaam, the commercial capital of Tanzania, where she opened a clothing store called Tabby Designs in 2006. She runs the store with one employee and the assistance of her children, all of whom are also enrolled in school. Tabitha sells traditional African cloth (called boutque), unique handcrafted accessories, and handicrafts to locals and tourists. The outfit you see Tabitha wearing in this picture is one she has made herself from boutque cloth! She has been making a monthly profit of approximately 500 USD from her store that she uses to supplement her husband's income and contribute to the family. Tabitha is requesting a first-time loan of 450 USD to purchase cloth and dyes to customize the traditional clothing that she sells. Tabitha is an exceptionally hard worker who spends eleven hours per day at her store for six days a week. In the future, with increased profits earned as a result of anticipated increased sales of her unique goods, Tabitha hopes to improve the quantity and range of products offered at her store.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of microcredit in Tanzania. The organization is devoted to the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through microfinance as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets; because of this, they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support, hence poor access to basic needs and services. When a client needs working capital to buy a specific item, SELFINA buys the equipment for said client and extends a loan to her. The same equipment is then leased back to the client so they can use it while in process of paying back their loan, a process called a sale-and-leaseback arrangement. Once the loan has been repaid, SELFINA transfers the ownership of the equipment to the client. The advantage of microleasing over traditional microfinance loans is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials for her clothing business

loans.name: Kheng

texts.en: KH. K. H., 27, raises pigs in her home with her husband, Meang Sin, in Siem Reap. They typically make US$10 per day and they have three young children to support. One of their children is a student in the local public school system, while the other two are still too young to attend school. KH. K. H. has asked for a loan of US$1000 to purchase 10 piglets to breed for additional income. She would also like to use some of the money to purchase feed for the pigs. Raising pigs is a profitable business in Cambodia and the family would like to see this business continue to grow in the future. After this loan is repaid, they will consider expanding the pig's barn to accommodate their growing business.

loans.use: Purchase 10 piglets to raise and breed

loans.name: Melisa

texts.en:
Melisa is a married woman from the town of Tesanj. Her husband is currently employed, while she works as a cashier for a betting house--a place where people can put bets on sports, races, and other competitions.

To supplement her income, Melisa has been working a side job selling cosmetics. She is able to order a large batch from a wholesale retailer and resell to people in her town, and can earn an extra 300 KM a month through this job.

Melisa is taking this, her second loan out in the amount of 1000 KM, which she will use to buy more cosmetics. It is Melisa's wish to earn enough to meet their household expenses, and also start to save some money. It is her dream to next year take some time off and have a vacation, something she has not been able to do for a long time.

loans.use: To buy cosmetics for resale

loans.name: Fatma's Asaa Khery Group

texts.en:
Fatma is a 48 year old single woman with 2 children, aged 17 and 6. She sells "bites", the local name for bread and cake. Every day, she works from 6 A.M. to 7 P.M. at her business where she can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

Fatma now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Afua and Tatu, who have businesses selling bites, charcoal and firewood.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Asha's Jambo Nia Group

texts.en:
Asha is a 29 year old married woman with 3 children, aged 11, 9 and 3. She has been a spice seller since 2007. Every day, she works from 8 A.M. to 8 P.M. at her business where she can earn a monthly profit of about $25 from her sales.

Asha now hopes for a loan to buy more spices for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have a tailoring business, a salon, and businesses selling clothing, juice, and keeping livestock.

loans.use: To buy more spices for her business

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! Rehema is the owner of a Mama Lishe (or local café) in the Kinondoni area of Dar es Salaam where she prepares and serves delicious Tanzanian cuisine to her customers. When you see a SELFINA entrepreneur whose business is a restaurant or café, you may have to adjust your mental image of what that is. A local restaurant or café in Tanzania usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long, wooden benches, with the sky as a ceiling. Such places don't even appear in the Lonely Planet's budget guide, but if you're looking for a cheap and tasty meal, and someone to have a chat with, this is the place to be. The food is all local: rice, ugali (a hot sticky dough, made from maize flour), plantain (a cooked savoury banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of yummy sauces. Rehema is currently able to make monthly profits of 200 USD from her Mama Lishe that she uses to support her family. As a thirty-two-year-old single mother of three children under the age of twelve, her business is indispensable to her family's well being. Rehema is requesting is requesting a loan of 300 USD to allow her to purchase supplies such as larger cooking utensils and chairs, which will allow her to expand her business to serve more customers. She is hopeful that this will help increase her profits from her business.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of microcredit in Tanzania. The organization is devoted to the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through microfinance as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets; because of this, they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support, hence poor access to basic needs and services. When a client needs working capital to buy a specific item, SELFINA buys the equipment for said client and extends a loan to her. The same equipment is then leased back to the client so they can use it while in process of paying back their loan, a process called a sale-and-leaseback arrangement. Once the loan has been repaid, SELFINA transfers the ownership of the equipment to the client. The advantage of microleasing over traditional microfinance loans is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase supplies for her cafe

loans.name: Halima S.

texts.en: Halima Ramadhan is a Tanzanian business woman. She runs a shop from which she sells a variety of items including cereal crop products. Items are purchased from Kariakoo city shopping centers and then sold in Buguruni. Her family depends on the business income to meet their daily demands. Her business dream is to one day run a wholesale shop. She is requesting a loan of  $350 to expand her business.

loans.use: To expand the business

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! Mariam is a fifty-six-year-old enterprising entrepreneur who successfully runs two small businesses, a Mama Lishe (or local café) and a beauty salon in Dar es Salaam by working for thirteen hours a day every day of the week. When you see a SELFINA entrepreneur whose business is a restaurant or café, you may have to adjust your mental image of what that is. A local café in Tanzania usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long, wooden benches, with the sky as a ceiling. Such places don't even appear in the Lonely Planet's budget guide, but if you're looking for a cheap and tasty meal, and someone to have a chat with, this is the place to be. The food is all local: rice, ugali (a hot sticky dough, made from maize flour), plantain (a cooked savory banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of yummy sauces. Mariam operates her businesses with the assistance of two employees and her children. She is requesting a 275 USD loan to expand her café. Specifically, she intends to use the loan to purchase soft drinks and juice for her clients, and to buy tables and chairs to allow her to serve more customers. Mariam is a widow who supports her six children, two of whom are under the age of eighteen, so increased profits from the café will be used towards family expenses.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of microcredit in Tanzania. The organization is devoted to the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through microfinance as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets; because of this, they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support, hence poor access to basic needs and services. When a client needs working capital to buy a specific item, SELFINA buys the equipment for said client and extends a loan to her. The same equipment is then leased back to the client so they can use it while in process of paying back their loan, a process called a sale-and-leaseback arrangement. Once the loan has been repaid, SELFINA transfers the ownership of the equipment to the client. The advantage of microleasing over traditional microfinance loans is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more supplies for her cafe

loans.name: Aminata

texts.fr:
Ms. Aminata Traoré, age 40, lives with her five children and her husband in a monogamous family in the Hérémakono Nord district of the city of Bougouni (third economic region of the Republic of Mali). From a young age, she started to earn an income, notably in catering, which she learned from her sister twenty years ago.

She has been working with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso for four years and is on her second individual loan, after having completed three group loans (solidarity loans) with an association in her district. All of the preceding loans have been correctly repaid.

This loan will serve to buy meat, Guinea fowl, chickens, fish (daily), a thousand kilograms of rice (Gambiaka and fragrant Thai ‘brizure’ for ‘fatty’ rice dishes), and large quantities of condiments, for a period of a month.

She gets her supplies of rice and condiments from different marketplaces in the city of Bamako (capital of the Republic of Mali) from specialized wholesalers in the applicable domains.

She makes several dishes: rice (‘fatty’ rice, and rice with tomato, okra, and peanut sauces); soups made with meat, Guinea fowl, chicken, or fish; fried foods; stews; and grilled foods: kebabs of meat and ‘capitaine’ (a kind of river fish).

Her sales outlet is located in the grand marketplace of the city of Bougouni, where there are large crowds of individuals, such as travelers, ‘night owls’, and truck drivers. She intends to realize a monthly profit of 45,000 francs CFA that she will use to cover the loan interest and to help with family expenses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, a Kiva volunteer

Madame Aminata Traoré, âgée de 40 ans vit avec ses 5 enfants et son époux dans une famille monogame au quartier Hérémakono Nord de la ville de Bougouni (troisième région économique de la république du Mali). Dès son jeune âge, elle a commencé les activités économiques notamment la restauration qu’elle a apprise auprès de sa soeur depuis maintenant 20 ans.

Elle travaille avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis 4 ans et est à son deuxième prêt indivuduel, après avoir bouclé trois prêts de groupe ( prêt solidaire) avec une assocaition de son quartier. Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.

Ce prêt servira à l’achat de viandes, de pintades, de poulets, de poissons (quotidiennement), de 1000 kg riz (Gambiaka et brizure thaïlandais parfumé pour le riz au gras ) et d’importantes quantités de condiments alimentaires pour une période d’un mois.

Elle s’approvisionne en riz et condiments alimentaires aux differents marchés de la ville de Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali) auprès des grossistes spécialisés des domaines concernés.

Elle prépare plusieurs plats: riz (riz au gras, riz avec sauces tomate, gombo et arachide) les soupes de viande, de pintade, de poulet et de poisson, les fritures, les râgouts et les grillades: brochettes de viande et de capitaine.

Son lieu de vente se trouve au grand marché de la ville de Bougouni où il ya une grande affluence d’individus comme les voyageurs les noctambules et les routiers. Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 45 000FCFA qu’elle utilisera pour payer les intérêts du prêt et contribuer aux dépenses de la famille.

loans.use: To buy Guinea fowl, chickens, rice, and condiments

loans.name: Sheila

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! Sheila is the owner of a Mama Lishe or local café in Dar es Salaam. When you see a SELFINA entrepreneur whose business is a restaurant or café, you may have to adjust your mental image of what that is. A local restaurant or café in Tanzania usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long, wooden benches, with the sky as a ceiling. Such places don't even appear in the Lonely Planet's budget guide, but if you're looking for a cheap and tasty meal, and someone to have a chat with, this is the place to be. The food is all local: rice, ugali (a hot sticky dough, made from maize flour), plantain (a cooked savory banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of yummy sauces. As a forty-year-old divorced mother of four (one of her children is still in school), profits from the café are essential to helping her family satisfy their daily needs. Sheila started her café in 2002 and has since been earning a monthly profit of 200 USD, which she uses towards school fees and food for the family. Sheila is requesting a loan of 275 USD to expand her café and help propel her business to increased profits and her family to an improved standard of living. The loan will be used to purchase cutlery, crockery, and more chairs for her customers. Sheila is a hard worker who can be found at her café for long hours every day of the week! Sheila would like to be successful enough to expand her café to other locations.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of microcredit in Tanzania. The organization is devoted to the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through microfinance as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. loans.use: To purchase supplies for her cafe

loans.name: Chhorn

texts.en:
Mr. Chhorn C., 55 years old, sells pieces of wood chopped from the forest, earning approximately $5.00 per day, while his wife, Mrs. Rek Mala, 53 years old, grows produce such as tomatoes and beans to sell. They live with two children, both of whom are married, in Contraing Commune, Siem Reap Province.

Now Mr. Chun is seeking a loan of $1,200 to purchase two oxen to transport the chopped wood, with the remainder being used to buy additional fertilizer for his wife’s produce business. The loan will increase their businesses’ sustainability and profits, and also help to improve their family's standard of living.

About Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL): HKL is one of Cambodia's largest and most successful microfinance institutions (MFIs). It is committed to helping its clients achieve their business goals by providing sound financial services, and thereby hopes to contribute to the social and economic development of Cambodia. HKL specifically targets women and poor families in order to help them achieve increased financial security and quality of life by offering various credit programs and encouraging savings. In accordance with its mission and its commitment to operational and financial sustainability, HKL contributes part of its net profits every year to support social development in education and healthcare.

loans.use: To purchase two oxen to transport the chopped wood as well as fertilizer for his wife's produce business

loans.name: Firangiz

texts.en: Firangiz was born in 1959 and is the mother of 3 children. She is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Kalbadjar region in the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan, now settled in the town of Khirdalan. 14 years ago Firangiz's brother (in the picture) started a business selling building materials.  Now Firangiz and her brother need a loan of $1200 to buy spare parts to improve their business.

loans.use: To buy spare parts

loans.name: Fatma Abdallah Asaa Khery Group

texts.en:
Fatma A. is a 28 year old married woman with 3 children, aged 14, 12 and 4. She owns a food shop and she has also been a charcoal and firewood seller since 2006. Every day, Fatma works from 7 A.M. to 4 P.M. at her business where she can earn a monthly profit of about $60 from her sales.

Fatma now hopes for a loan to buy more charcoal, firewood and food items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members who own a salon, a kiosk (mini-shop), a shop, and a business selling juice and charcoal.

loans.use: To increase her inventory by buying more charcoal, firewood and food items for her business

loans.name: Ashura's Ujamaa Group

texts.en:
Ashura is a married woman with 4 children, aged 13, 9, 6 and 1. She is an oil seller. Every day, she works from 7 AM to 9.30 PM at her business where she can earn a monthly profit of about $30 from her sales.

Ashura now hopes for a loan to buy more oil for resale. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who also have businesses selling porridge, fish, and snacks.

loans.use: To purchase oil for resale

loans.name: Sim

texts.en:
Mrs. Sim P. lives in Angk Tapok Village in Kampong Spue, Cambodia. She is a farmer and Khmer noodle maker and makes little income. She now faces a problem on her plantation because her field is infertile. She has decided to request a loan to buy fertilizer for the field and she would use the remainder of the loan to buy sticky-rice to make Khmer noodle.

Mrs. Sim P. is a 51-year-old widow with four children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while the others are attending school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for the field and any remaining funds would be used to buy sticky-rice to make Khmer noodle.

loans.name: Arafa

texts.en:
Arafa is a thirty-three-year-old mother and small business owner from Dar es Salaam. She is the owner of a "Mama Lishe" or local café that serves up delicious meals at affordable prices. When you see a SELFINA entrepreneur whose business title is "restaurant" or "café," you may have to adjust your mental image of what that is. A local restaurant or café in Tanzania usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long, wooden benches, with the sky as a ceiling. Such places don't even appear in the Lonely Planet's budget guide, but if you're looking for a cheap and tasty meal, and someone to have a chat with, this is the place to be. The food is all local; rice, ugali (a hot sticky dough, made from maize flour), plantain (a cooked savory banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of yummy sauces. Despite only being in business since 2007, Arafa's enterprise has grown to require the help of an additional employee and generate monthly profits of 250 USD. She uses the money earned from her café to support her twelve-year-old son who is enrolled in school. Additionally, she is also the provider for a local orphan.

Arafa is requesting a loan of $275, which she intends to use to purchase additional stocks of rice, cooking oil, and wheat flour. With the increased profits that she hopes this will generate, Arafa plans to improve the standard of living of her family. In the future, she aspires to expand her café to new locations as well as increase the scale of her operation.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of microcredit in Tanzania. The organization is devoted to the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through microfinance as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets; because of this, they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support, hence poor access to basic needs and services. When a client needs working capital to buy a specific item, SELFINA buys the equipment for said client and extends a loan to her. The same equipment is then leased back to the client so they can use it while in process of paying back their loan, a process called a sale-and-leaseback arrangement. Once the loan has been repaid, SELFINA transfers the ownership of the equipment to the client. The advantage of microleasing over traditional microfinance loans is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase additional cooking supplies for her cafe

loans.name: Elizabeti

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! Elizabeti is thirty-six years old and married with three children, two of whom are in school. She has an additional dependent, Benjamin, whom she takes care of because his parents are unable to provide for him. She owns a beauty salon in Dar es Salaam that she runs along with one employee and with the assistance of her children. Hair, hair and more hair! This is the place where you can buy long hair, short hair, curly hair, straight hair, red hair, blue hair, and then have it attached to your head, woven, cut, or braided, and made to look like your own. Elizabeti earns about 300 USD per month from the salon as a result of working long hours every day of the week. She is requesting a loan of 275 USD to purchase cosmetics, wigs, and other hair products for her salon. In the future, with increased profits gained by serving additional clients, Elizabeti hopes to expand her business.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of microcredit in Tanzania. The organization is devoted to the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through microfinance as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets; because of this, they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support, hence poor access to basic needs and services.
