The same equipment is then leased back to the client so they can use it while in process of paying back their loan, a process called a sale-and-leaseback arrangement. Once the loan has been repaid, SELFINA transfers the ownership of the equipment to the client. The advantage of microleasing over traditional microfinance loans is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.g

loans.use: To buy additional supplies for her beauty salon

loans.name: Salimata

texts.fr:
Ms. Salimata Samaké is 34 years old, has five children, and lives in the Hérémakono Nord district of the city of Bougouni (Sikasso Region, Republic of Mali) in a polygamous family with her two co-wives, their children, and their husband.

From a young age, she started earning an income, which she was obliged to set aside for reasons of marriage (immigration to the Republic of Cote d’Ivoire). Back in Mali, she started working again, specializing for ten years in the sale of Wax pagnes (highly prized cloth in West Africa), beauty products, and children’s clothing.

She has been associated with Soro Yiriwaso for three years now. After having completed three group loans (solidarity loans) with an association in her district, she is on her second individual loan. And all of the preceding loans have been correctly repaid.

She intends to use this loan to buy 20 dozen items of children’s clothing, 15 dozen bed sheets, and 30 lengths of Wax pages (cloth that is highly prized by women in West Africa). She gets her supplies exclusively from Bamako (capital of the Republic of Mali) from wholesalers recognized in her specialization. Her sales outlet is located in the grand marketplace of the city of Bougouni.

She makes retail sales, by cash and on credit payable monthly, especially for salaried workers. Her customers are composed of women for the most part. She hopes to realize a monthly profit of 50,000 francs CFA, which will serve to cover the loan interest and to begin construction on her house, in order to get away from the trials and tribulations of renting.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, a Kiva volunteer

Madame Salimata Samaké a 34 ans, 5 enfants et vit dans le quartier Hérémakono Nord de la ville de Bougouni (Région de Sikasso République du Mali ) dans une famille polygame avec ses 2 coépouses leurs enfants et leur époux.

Dès son jeune âge elle commença les activités génératrices de revenus qu’elle fut obligée de mettre en veilleuse pour des raisons de mariage (immigration vers la République de la Côte d’ivoire). De retour au Mali, elle reprend les activités économiques en se spécialisant dans la vente des pagnes wax (tissu très prisé en Afrique de l’ouest), des produits de beauté et des vêtements pour enfants, il y ’a de cela 10 ans.

Elle est en relation avec Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 3 ans. Après avoir bouclé trois prêts de groupe (prêt solidaire) avec une association de son quartier elle est à son deuxième prêt individuel et tous les précédents ont été correctement remboursés.

Elle compte utiliser ce prêt pour acheter, 20 douzaines de vêtements pour enfants, 15 douzaines de draps de lits, 30 pièces de pagnes wax (tissu très prisé par les femmes en Afrique de l’Ouest) Elle s’approvisionne exclusivement à partir de Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali) auprès de grossistes reconnus du domaine de sa spécialisation. Son lieu de vente est situé au grand marché de la ville de Bougouni.

Elle vend en détail au comptant et à crédit payable mensuellement surtout aux salariés. Sa clientèle est composée en grande majorité de femmes. Elle espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 50 000 FCFA qui servira à payer les intérêts du prêt et à commencer la construction de sa maison pour se défaire des péripéties de la location.

loans.use: To buy children's clothing and Wax pagnes cloth

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en: Mrs. Ruth S., 20, is employed by a garment factory and can make about $1.60 each day. Her husband, 22, is a motor-taxi driver transporting passengers to different locations, earning around $2.50 each day. There are five members in her family. Her oldest sister works as a farmer and her parent is too old to work. Mrs. Ruth S. and her husband have humbly requested for a loan to purchase a motor-bike to replace their old one. (Her husband is pictured because Mrs. Ruth S. is not available).

loans.use: Ruth would like to purchase another motor-bike to replace her old one.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.fr:
Ms. Agnès Berthé is 36 years old and lives with her three children (one boy and two girls), her husband, and parents in a large, traditional, extended family in Kôkô district of Koutiala Prefecture (third economic region of Mali).

From a tender age, she started earning income in all kinds of ways but decided in the end to specialize in the transformation of “néré en Sounbala” seeds (a natural condiment with many virtues). She learned how to do this very early on from her mom (like most women of her ethnic group: the Minianka). She has been doing this work in her home for fifteen years. To obtain the supplementary financial resources, she decided to turn to the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with which she is on her first individual loan.

She gets her basic supplies in the villages surrounding Koutiala on market days. With this loan, she intends to buy 30 sacks of néré seeds of different grades that she will have taken to Koutiala. These seeds are pounded, boiled, and crushed and then transformed into rounded forms or into a powder. Next, these Sounbala are put into a container for sale in bulk in Koutiala with enterprises at the marketplace or in the home. A portion of the production is dispatched to Sikasso and to Bamako (capital of the Republic of Mali) and is sold on credit, payable monthly, and sometimes by cash, to customers essentially made up of women and retailers.

With this new loan, she intends to realize a monthly profit of 100,000 francs CFA that she intends to use to cover the loan interest and to help with family expenses, the bulk of which falls upon her shoulders.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, a Kiva volunteer

Madame Agnès Berthé est âgée de 36 ans et vit avec ses 3 enfants (1 garçon et 2 filles) son mari et des parents dans une grande famille traditionnelle élargie au quartier Kôkô de la préfecture de Koutiala (troisième région économique du Mali)

Depuis sa tendre enfance elle commence les activités génératrices de revenus de toutes sortes, mais décide finalement de se spécialiser dans la transformation des graines de néré en Sounbala (un condiment alimentaire naturel aux vertus multiples) qu’elle apprena très tôt auprès de sa maman (comme la plupart des femmes de son ethnie : les Minianka). Elle exerce cette activité à son domicile il y a de cela 15 ans. Pour obtenir des ressources financières complémentaires elle décida de faire recourt à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elle est à son premier prêt individuel.

Elle s’approvisionne en matières premières dans les villages environnants de Koutiala pendant les jours de foire. Avec ce prêt elle compte acheter 30 sacs de graine de néré de différentes qualités qu’elle fera acheminer à Koutiala. Ces graines sont pilées, bouillies avant d’être écrasées et transformées en boules de différentes formes ou en poudre. Ensuite ces Sounbala sont mises dans des récipients pour la vente en vrac à Koutiala au niveau des entreprises au marché ou à la maison. Une partie de la production est expédiée à Sikasso et à Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali) et vendue à crédit payable mensuellement, quelque fois au comptant, à une clientèle essentiellement constituée de femmes et de revendeurs.

Avec ce nouveau prêt elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000 FCFA qu’elle compte utiliser pour payer les intérêts du prêt et participer aux dépense de la famille dont l'essentielle repose sur elle.

loans.use: To by néré seeds

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! Joyce is a forty-five-year-old single mother with one child and an additional dependent, an orphan who is a relative. She owns a soft drink store in Dar es Salaam, which she runs with two employees. It is said that "Coca Cola" is one of the most recognized symbols or names in the world. And it's true. Even in the most remote villages in Africa, there is usually some kind of "bar" selling Coke, Fanta, and Guiness. The hot weather makes soft drinks all the more appealing, which explains why selling soft drinks is such a popular venture. Joyce's monthly profit from her store is approximately 100 USD. She is requesting a loan of $525 to purchase additional soft drinks and equipment like refrigerators for her store.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of microcredit in Tanzania. The organization is devoted to the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through microfinance as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets; because of this, they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support, hence poor access to basic needs and services. When a client needs working capital to buy a specific item, SELFINA buys the equipment for said client and extends a loan to her. The same equipment is then leased back to the client so they can use it while in process of paying back their loan, a process called a sale-and-leaseback arrangement. Once the loan has been repaid, SELFINA transfers the ownership of the equipment to the client. The advantage of microleasing over traditional microfinance loans is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase additional soft drinks and a refrigerator

loans.name: Danaya (La Confiance Group

texts.fr:
Danaya is a group of two married women and two girls in the Sogomougou district of the city of Koutiala (third economic region of the Republic of Mali). They average 26 years of age and live in polygamous families with their husbands, co-spouses, and many other parents.

They are involved in different businesses: catering, buying and selling used clothing, food stuffs, beauty products, etc. Concerned with increasing the size of their businesses, the members of the Danaya Group decided to join the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso two years ago. The group is on its second loan after having correctly repaid the first one.

The current loan will be used to buy 2 boxes of beauty products and a bundle of second-hand clothing from Bamako (capital of the Republic of Mali), 5 bags of beans (in the villages surrounding the city of Koutiala) to make beignets (a kind of doughnut or fritter), and a sizeable quantity of ingredients.

They are experienced and enjoy a great deal of fame in their respective domains. They sell their goods in front of their homes, at the marketplace of the Sogomougou district, or retail door-to-door, cash or credit accepted, to customers essentially composed of women and children.

They each intend to realize an average profit of 90,000 francs CFA, which will be used to cover the loan interest and family expenses, and the rest will be invested in their businesses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, a Kiva volunteer

Danaya est un regroupement de deux femmes mariées et deux jeunes filles du quartier Sogomougou de la ville de Koutiala (troisième région éconmique de la république du Mali ) ayant une moyenne d’âge de 26 ans. Elles vivent dans des familles polygames avec leurs maris, des coépouses et bien d’autres parents.

Elles mènent differentes activités: la restauration, l’achat vente des fripperies, des produits alimentaires , des produits de beauté etc. Dans leur souci d’augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres du groupe Danaya ont décidé d’intégrer le programme de crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis deux ans. Le groupe est à son deuxième prêt après avoir correctement remboursé le premier.

Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter, deux cartons de produits de beauté et un ballot de fripperie à partir de Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali), 5 sacs de haricot (dans les villages environnants de la ville de Koutiala) pour faire des beignets et une quantité importante d’ingrédients.

Elles sont expérimentées et jouissent d’une grande notoriété dans leur domaine respectif. Elles vendent leurs produits devant leurs domiciles, au marché du quartier de Sogomougou, de façon ambulante en détail au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle essentiellement composée de femmes et d’enfants.

Elles comptent réaliser chacune en moyenne 90 000FCFA. de bénéfice qui sera utilisé pour payer les intérêts du prêt , subvenir aux dépenses de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités.

loans.use: To buy second-hand clothing, beignets ingredients, and beauty products

loans.name: Saida

texts.en:
Saida is a forty-two-year-old married woman with four children, all of whom are in school. She rears kuku for sale. Raising kuku is a popular micro-business in Tanzania, especially amongst SELFINA clients. What are kuku, you may ask? Kuku means chickens in Swahili, and raising them for sale is popular because they require little startup capital, require little space, and their eggs can be sold or eaten. Saida is assisted in her poultry business by one employee, her husband, and her children. Her monthly profit is approximately 120 USD. She is seeking a 275 USD loan to purchase additional chicks and feed that she hopes will help her breed more chickens for sale.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of microcredit in Tanzania. The organization is devoted to the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through microfinance as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets; because of this, they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support, hence poor access to basic needs and services. The same equipment is then leased back to the client so they can use it while in process of paying back their loan, a process called a sale-and-leaseback arrangement. Once the loan has been repaid, SELFINA transfers the ownership of the equipment to the client. The advantage of microleasing over traditional microfinance loans is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy additional chicks and feed

loans.name: Keng

texts.en:
Mrs. Keng K., 45, is the mother of six children and lives in Kampong Chhnang province, Cambodia. To make her standard of living, Mrs. Keng K. breeds pigs at her home, making around $3 each day in revenue. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver transporting passengers to different locations in his town, earning around $3 each day of income. 
In the early morning, she starts giving food and bathing her pigs and at noon and in the evening she does the same thing. Doing so frequently will make her pigs healthy and grow fast. The pig food she buys from the market is not enough for her livestock supplies, so what she has to do is collect the waste of food from her neighbor's houses in bulk and cooks them with morning glory. This loan is her second loan with KIVA. She was so impressive with the impact of the loan on her family and her business. Recently, Mrs. Keng K. has applied for a loan to purchase more piglets and pig's food for her pigs.

loans.use: To purchase more piglets and pig's food for her livestock.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase raw materials to keep produce fried dishes.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To invest in more clothing to add to her stock.

loans.name: Ester

texts.en:
Ester is a thirty-three-year-old married woman with four children, three of whom are in school. She also supports an additional dependent who is an orphan. She owns a local Mama Lishe in Dar es Salaam, or small café, that she runs with two employees to return a monthly profit of about 500 USD. When you see a SELFINA entrepreneur whose business title is "restaurant" or "café," you may have to adjust your mental image of what that is. A local restaurant or café in Tanzania usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long, wooden benches, with the sky as a ceiling. Such places don't even appear in the Lonely Planet's budget guide, but if you're looking for a cheap and tasty meal, and someone to have a chat with, this is the place to be. The food is all local; rice, ugali (a hot sticky dough, made from maize flour), plantain (a cooked savory banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of yummy sauces. Ester is requesting a loan of 275 USD to purchase additional stocks of rice, cooking oil, maize and wheat flour. In the future, she would like to open another Mama Lishe to serve her delicious food to even more customers!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of microcredit in Tanzania. The organization is devoted to the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through microfinance as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets; because of this, they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support, hence poor access to basic needs and services. When a client needs working capital to buy a specific item, SELFINA buys the equipment for said client and extends a loan to her. The same equipment is then leased back to the client so they can use it while in process of paying back their loan, a process called a sale-and-leaseback arrangement. Once the loan has been repaid, SELFINA transfers the ownership of the equipment to the client. The advantage of microleasing over traditional microfinance loans is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase additional supplies for her cafe

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To invest in a stock of shoes for her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase clothing in order to keep running her small business.

loans.name: Benkadi (L’Union Fait La Force Group

texts.fr:
Benkadi ("Together we are strong") is a group of seven women from the first district of the city of Koutiala (region of Sikasso, Republic of Mali). The group members average 37 years of age, are married, and are mothers with at least five children each. They all live in traditional polygamous families with their parents-in-law, co-spouses, children, their husbands, and brothers and sisters.

Linked by ties of profession, blood, and marriage, these women do dye work (learned from parents practicing this work) and commerce in beauty products, dried smoked fish, etc.

Concerned about increasing the size of their businesses, the members decided to join the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso four years ago. They have already benefited from nine loans, and each of the preceding ones was correctly repaid.

The current loan will be used to buy 5 boxes of beauty products (from Bamako, the capital of the Republic of Mali) from wholesalers, some baskets of smoked and dried fish (from Korientzé, a fishing village in Mopti Prefecture), and a sizeable quantity of ingredients for dye work (on location at the grand marketplace of the city of Koutiala) from stall-keepers selling at the market.

These women of the Benkadi Group are very enterprising and known for the quality of their work. Their goods are sold retail, cash and often credit accepted, in the districts of the city of Koutiala. The goods are sold door-to-door and in the marketplaces of neighboring villages, to a customer base made up essentially of caterers, retailers, and women.

They intend to realize an average profit of 100,000 francs CFA, which will be used to cover the loan interest, to address family expenses, and to invest the rest in the businesses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, a Kiva volunteer

Benkadi est un regroupement de sept femmes du premier quartier de la ville de Koutiala (région de Sikasso république du Mali) ayant une moyenne d’âge de 37 ans, mariées et mères d’au moins 5 enfants chacune. Elles vivent toutes dans des familles polygames traditionnelles avec les beaux parents, des coépouses, les enfants, leurs maris et des frères et soeurs.

Liées par des relations professionnelles, de parenté et de mariage, ces femmes font de la teinture (apprise auprès de parents exerçant cette activité) et le commerce des produits de beauté, des poissons fumés séchés etc.

Dans leur souci d’augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidé d’intégrer le programme de crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant quatre ans. Elles ont bénéficié déjà de neuf prêts et tous les précédents ont été correctement remboursés.

Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter, 5 cartons de produits de beauté (de Bamako capitale de la république du Mali, auprès des grossistes), des paniers de poissons fumés et séchés (à partir de Korientzé une localité piscicole de la préfecture de Mopti) et une quantité importante d’ingrédients pour la teinture (sur place au grand marché de la ville de Koutiala auprès des forains fréquentant les foires).

Très entreprenantes et réputées pour la qualité de leurs activités, les produits de ces femmes du groupe Benkadi sont vendus au comptant en détail souvant à crédit dans les quartiers la ville de Koutiala de façon ambulante et les marchés des villages voisins à une clientèle essentiellement constituée de restaurateurs, de revendeurs et de femmes.

Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 100 000FCFA. qui sera utilisé pour payer les intérêts du prêt, faire face aux charges de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités.

loans.use: To buy beauty products, fish, and basic ingredients for dye work

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! Josephine is a forty-year-old widow with two children under the age of eighteen, and she also takes care of an orphan who is a relative. She runs a local Mama Lishe, or small café, with three employees to generate a monthly profit of 700 USD. When you see a SELFINA entrepreneur whose business title is "restaurant" or "café," you may have to adjust your mental image of what that is. A local restaurant or café in Tanzania usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long, wooden benches, with the sky as a ceiling. Such places don't even appear in the Lonely Planet's budget guide, but if you're looking for a cheap and tasty meal, and someone to have a chat with, this is the place to be. The food is all local; rice, ugali (a hot sticky dough, made from maize flour), plantain (a cooked savory banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of yummy sauces. Josephine also works as a caterer for local businesses on an as-needed basis, which has helped her increase her monthly profit immensely. She is requesting 450 USD to purchase additional serving equipment to help fulfill her catering orders and extra cooking supplies such as rice and potatoes.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of microcredit in Tanzania. The organization is devoted to the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through microfinance as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. The same equipment is then leased back to the client so they can use it while in process of paying back their loan, a process called a sale-and-leaseback arrangement. Once the loan has been repaid, SELFINA transfers the ownership of the equipment to the client. The advantage of microleasing over traditional microfinance loans is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase additional supplies for her café

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To invest in a various goods to restock a small grocery store.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! Agnes is a fifty year old widowed mother of seven children, two of whom are in school. She owns a small store, which she runs with two employees, from which she sells traditional Tanzanian cloth with which one can tailor outfits. The choice of colors and types of material of cloth that she sells is quite varied! Her store currently generates a monthly profit of $300. She is requesting $275 to purchase additional stocks of cloth for her business. Agnes intends to spend the increased profits that she hopes this loan will generate on her family and hopes to expand her business in the near future.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase food ingredients and a large quantity of alcoholic beverages to serve.

loans.name: Shamil

texts.en: Shamil J. is a 37-year-old man who has been making window frames and doors of wood for more than 20 years. He lives and works in a small village in the Imishli region. He is married and has 3 children. Shamil has applied for a loan in the amount of 1200 USD to purchase modern machines and develop his business.

loans.use: to purchase modern machines for his carpentry business

loans.name: Mayak

texts.en: Mayak A. is a 19-year-old man who tends a food store. He started his business in the beginning of 2008 and right now the main thing he is selling is beverages. Mayak has applied for a loan in the amount of 1000 USD to purchase more food products as tea, sugar, cookies, candies, etc. This will help him to expand his business and gain more profit from it.

loans.use: to purchase more food products as tea, sugar, etc. for re-sale

loans.name: Khokuma

texts.en: Khokuma J. is a 49-year-old woman who has been breeding calves in the southern region of Imishli since 1982. She is married  and has 3 daughters. She would like to expand her activity as this is the only financial resource in her family. Khokuma would like to start selling dairy products and for this purpose she has applied for a loan in the amount of  800 USD. She is going to spend this amount to purchase one cow.

loans.use: to purchase one milch cow

loans.name: Samira

texts.en: Samira A. is a 28-year-old woman who keeps a food store in the southern region of Imishli. She started her business in 1982. Samira supports her family, including her father and mother, who are on a pension. Samira would like to expand her food store, and to this purpose she applied for $1000.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Daïma Minmin

texts.fr:
Ms. Daïma Minmin M. was born February 14, 1976 in Parakou in northern Benin. She is married and has three children: Moussa, Nadjibou, and Imorou, who are in 1st grade, 3rd grade, and 6th grade, respectively. She specializes in food products, such as millet, sorghum, soda, yams, etc. She purchases most of her stock in the northern region of Benin and sometimes in Savalou, in central Benin. Currently, her stock is insufficient for her to satisfy her customer demand. In order to remedy this situation, she is requesting this loan so she can purchase her stock in the northern part of the country where products cheaper than in other regions of the country so she can keep up with customer demand and reinvest in her business as well.
Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer
Dame M. Daïma Minmin est née le 14 Février 1976 à Parakou dans le  Nord du BENIN. Mariée, elle est  mère de 03 enfants que sont Moussa, Nadjibou et Imorou respectivement en classe de CI, CE2 et 6 ème. Elle est spécialisée dans la  commercialisation  des produits vivriers tels que le mil, le sorgho, le soda, l'igname, etc. Elle s'approvisionne notamment dans la région nord du Bénin et quelques fois à SAVALOU au centre du Bénin. Actuellement le stock dont elle dispose ne lui permet pas de satisfaire la demande de sa clientèle. Pour parer à cette situation elle sollicite ce crédit pour s'approvisionner essentiellement dans le nord où les produits coûtent relativement moins chers pendant que dans les autres régions du pays afin de satisfaire la demande de sa clientèle et renforcer son activité.

loans.use: Purchase of 3 sacks of corn, 2 sacks of millet, and 2 sacks of yams

loans.name: Mobil

texts.en: Mobil D. is a 33-year-old man whose food store is in the southern region of Imishli. He has more than 10 years of experience. He has applied for a $1200 loan to improve the condition of his store.

loans.use: To improve the condition of his store

loans.name: Isi

texts.en: Isi O. is 44 years old, married and has five children. She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria, where she makes a living selling provisions and foodstuffs. Isi has been in business since 1998 and has decided to apply for a loan of $875 to buy a refrigerator because this will help her provide better service to her customers. She will also use a portion of the loan to buy more items to sell. She thanks you for your consideration and support.

loans.use: To buy a refrigerator and more items to sell to her customers

loans.name: Fatoumata

texts.fr:
Ms. Fatoumata S. is 45 years old and lives with her four children, husband, and her co-spouse in a polygamous family in the village of Sanankoroba in the sub-prefecture of Ouelessebougou (Kati Prefecture, region of Koulikoro, Republic of Mali).

She has had an association with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso for five years. After having completed four group loans with an association in her district, she is on her fourth individual loan, all repaid correctly. She intends use this loan to buy 60 Wax pagnes (highly prized cloth in West Africa) of different grades in the grand marketplace of Bamako (capital of the Republic of Mali) from wholesalers of the specialty area.

She sells her goods retail, cash accepted, and by credit payable monthly for salaried workers. These sales are made locally in Sanankoroba at fixed locations, and door-to-door, and also from displays at the marketplace on market days. Her customers are essentially composed of retailers and women. She intends to realize a profit of 45,000 francs CFA per month that will be used to cover the loan interest and family expenses and to invest the rest in business. In the future, Ms. Fatoumata S. intends to open a shop selling pagnes, specifically Wax pagnes.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva volunteer

Madame Fatoumata S. est âgée de 45 ans et vit avec ses 4 enfants, son mari et sa coépouse dans une famille polygame dans le village de Sanankoroba dans la sous préfecture de Ouelessebougou (Préfecture de Kati Région de Koulikoro République du Mali).

Elle est en relation avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis 5 ans. Après avoir bouclé 4 prêts de groupe avec une association de son quartier elle est à son quatrième prêt individuel et tous correctement remboursés. Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt, 60 pagnes wax (tissu très prisé en Afrique de l’Ouest) de différentes qualités au grand marché de Bamako (capitale de république du Mali) auprès des grossistes du domaine.

Elle vend ses produits en détail au comptant et à crédit payable mensuellement aux salariés sur place à Sanankoroba de façon fixe, ambulante et sur des étales au marché les jours de foire. Sa clientèle est essentiellement composée de revendeurs et de femmes. Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice de 45.000F CFA par mois qui sera utilisé pour payer les intérêts du prêt subvenir aux dépenses de la famille et investir le reste dans les affaires. Madame Fatoumata S. compte dans le futur ouvrir une boutique de vente de pagnes spécifiquement les pagnes wax.

loans.use: To buy Wax pagnes

loans.name: Jesca

texts.en:
Jesca is a 39-year-old married woman with three children, and she is also responsible for an additional dependent. She rears kuku for sale. Raising kuku is a popular micro-business in Tanzania, especially amongst SELFINA clients. Who or what are ‘kuku’, you may ask. "Kuku" means chickens in Swahili, and raising them for sale is popular for a number of reasons. Firstly, they require little start-up capital. You can start with one or two, and either add to them as you go, or wait for them to multiply naturally! Secondly, they require little space, so sometimes you can just let them run around in your garden or compound. Thirdly, while they are growing they produce eggs, which can either be sold to provide a supplementary source of income, or eaten to provide a supplementary source of protein.

Jesca established her poultry business in 2006 and she manages it with an employee. Her business model involves hatching and raising chicks and then selling them wholesale as chickens to the villagers at a premium. Her business makes about $US500 in profit per month. She is requesting a loan for $US450 to purchase additional chicks and feed.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence the poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. When a client needs working capital to buy a specific item, SELFINA buys the equipment for said client and extends a loan to her. The same equipment is then leased back to the client so they can use it while in process of paying back their loan – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement. Once the loan has been repaid, SELFINA transfers the ownership of the equipment to the client. The advantage of microleasing over traditional microfinance loans is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase additional chicks and feed

loans.name: Marie

texts.fr:
Born on March 31, 1973 in Porto-Novo in the Ouémé Department of southeastern Benin, Ms. Marie O. is married with three children, of which two, Arnaud and Brigitte, are in the 8th grade and 6th grade, respectively, and still under her care. She lives with her small family in Lokokoukoumé, a working-class district of the city of Cotonou where she sells various products. In addition to this, she also sells fabric to the public and private businesses in Cotonou. Currently, she is confronted with a high demand, yet her stock is insufficient to meet her customers’ needs. Therefore, she is requesting this loan so she can satisfy her client demand and also reinvest in her business.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

Née le 31 Mars 1973 à Porto-Novo dans le département de l'Ouémé au sud-est du BENIN, dame O. Marie est mariée et mère de trois enfants dont Arnaud et Brigitte respectivement en classe de quatrième et sixième sont encore à sa charge. Elle vit avec sa petite famille à LOKOKOUKOUME un quartier populaire de la ville de Cotonou où elle exerce son activité de vente de produits divers. Parallèlement à cette activité elle fait aussi de la distribution des tissus dans les sociétés publiques et privées de la ville de Cotonou. Actuellement, elle est confrontée à une forte demande alors que son stock ne lui permet pas de couvrir les besoins de sa clientèle. C'est dans cette optique qu'elle sollicite ce prêt afin de répondre favorablement à la demande de sa clientèle et aussi de renforcer le niveau de son activité.

loans.use: Purchase of 6 rolls of fabric, a dozen ladies' purses, 2 dozen tins of sardines, and 3 cartons of spaghetti
